Award.AwardTitle: Molecular Evolution of Genes Expressed in D. Melanogaster Sperm Storage Structures.
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is designed to investigate genes expressed in sperm storage organs (SSOs) in female Drosophila melanogaster. SSOs potentially play an important role in a range of evolutionary phenomena including co-evolution and speciation. Given the prominent role of D. melanogaster as a model for evolutionary and genetic studies, it is surprising that so little is known about the evolution of genes characteristically expressed in SSOs and that little is known about the function of these genes. The investigators will examine the function of a set of these genes defined by molecular evolution data, molecular population genetic data and information suggesting that certain genes play a direct role in sperm storage.

The sequences generated from this project will be deposited in the public database, NCBI/GenBank, in timely manner. A project website will be developed to provide information about the progress of the research and to provide the research community access to all sequence data. The grant will contribute to educational outcomes in various ways. First, both graduate and undergraduate students will be involved in the research. Second, the co-PI (Moriyama) will incorporate statistical methods used in the project and the results into her course. Third, the PI (Harshman) will expand the population genetic component of his honors human genetics course and its graduate student counterpart.

Institution.Name: University of Nebraska-Lincoln
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Genes related to reproduction are known to disproportionately evolve rapidly from research on a vast range of taxa. Rapidly evolving reproductive genes in Drosophila have been the subject of studies. However, the majority of such studies have focused on male Drosophila reproductive proteins, and only a limited number of investigations have been done on the evolution of proteins expressed in specific female reproductive organs.  D. melanogaster females have two sperm storage organs: the seminal receptacle and paired spermathecae. The seminal receptacle stores the majority (65–80%) of the sperm, and the spermathecae is thought to be the long-term sperm storage organ.

 

Previously, we investigated molecular evolution in a specific sperm storage organ, the spermathecae, using evolutionary expressed sequence tag (EST) analysis and showed a high incidence of positive selection especially in protease genes (Prokupek et al. 2008). In Prokupek et al. (2009), we used transcriptome analysis to investigate expression differences in the two sperm storage organs at two time points post-mating. This study found substantial differences between the transcription profiles of these two organs. The spermathecae was enriched for genes involved in proteolysis and metabolism whereas the seminal receptacle was enriched for genes involved in localization, signaling and ion transport. In Prokupek et al. (2010), we further performed an evolutionary EST study of genes expressed in the seminal receptacle. The incidence of positive selection is higher for the seminal receptacle genes than Drosophila reproductive genes as a whole, but lower than genes associated with the spermatheca. To examine further the mode of selection operating in the genes expressed in female sperm storage organs, we chose six genes expressed in spermatheca and three genes expressed in seminal receptacle based on our previous studies. We re-sequenced these genes/gene regions from North American and African populations and performed neutrality tests. The results of these tests are completed and are in tabular form for publication.  The manuscript is now ready for submission:

 

Prokupek, Shah, Moriyama and Harshman. 2015. Molecular population genetic investigation of female sperm storage expressed genes in Drosophila melanogaster. Journal of Evolutionary Biology

 

The RNAi crosses to suppress specific gene expression, and importantly new control crosses (see major activities above) were repeated for 14 spermatheca genes.  This experimental was replicated for egg production, progeny production and remating incidence.  This research indicates that the effect of suppression of egg expression is to reduce the number of eggs laid and reduce the number of progeny produced.  This result is straight-forward to interpret in terms of diminution of gene expression and consequent reduction of the effect of wild-type gene expression. 

 

Importantly, all of the specific objectives of the grant have been accomplished.  Two evolutionary EST projects (one for each sperm storage organ), one transcriptome project (comparing the spermathecal and seminal receptacle), one molecular population genetic project (comparing an African and North American populations for candidate genes for both sperm storage organs) and tests of gene function using RNAi.


Last Modified: 01/31/2015
Modified by: Etsuko Moriyama
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Genes related to reproduction are known to disproportionately evolve rapidly from research on a vast range of taxa. Rapidly evolving reproductive genes in Drosophila have been the subject of studies. However, the majority of such studies have focused on male Drosophila reproductive proteins, and only a limited number of investigations have been done on the evolution of proteins expressed in specific female reproductive organs. D. melanogaster females have two sperm storage organs: the seminal receptacle and paired spermathecae. The seminal receptacle stores the majority (65–80%) of the sperm, and the spermathecae is thought to be the long-term sperm storage organ. Previously, we investigated molecular evolution in a specific sperm storage organ, the spermathecae, using evolutionary expressed sequence tag (EST) analysis and showed a high incidence of positive selection especially in protease genes (Prokupek et al. 2008). In Prokupek et al. (2009), we used transcriptome analysis to investigate expression differences in the two sperm storage organs at two time points post-mating. This study found substantial differences between the transcription profiles of these two organs. The spermathecae was enriched for genes involved in proteolysis and metabolism whereas the seminal receptacle was enriched for genes involved in localization, signaling and ion transport. In Prokupek et al. (2010), we further performed an evolutionary EST study of genes expressed in the seminal receptacle. The incidence of positive selection is higher for the seminal receptacle genes than Drosophila reproductive genes as a whole, but lower than genes associated with the spermatheca. We re-sequenced these genes/gene regions from North American and African populations and performed neutrality tests. The results of these tests are completed and are in tabular form for publication. The manuscript is now ready for submission: Prokupek, Shah, Moriyama and Harshman. 2015. Molecular population genetic investigation of female sperm storage expressed genes in Drosophila melanogaster. Journal of Evolutionary Biology The RNAi crosses to suppress specific gene expression, and importantly new control crosses (see major activities above) were repeated for 14 spermatheca genes. This experimental was replicated for egg production, progeny production and remating incidence. This research indicates that the effect of suppression of egg expression is to reduce the number of eggs laid and reduce the number of progeny produced. This result is straight-forward to interpret in terms of diminution of gene expression and consequent reduction of the effect of wild-type gene expression. Importantly, all of the specific objectives of the grant have been accomplished. Two evolutionary EST projects (one for each sperm storage organ), one transcriptome project (comparing the spermathecal and seminal receptacle), one molecular population genetic project (comparing an African and North American populations for candidate genes for both sperm storage organs) and tests of gene function using RNAi.
